question_text: What is the main neurotransmitter involved in migraine headaches?

options.A: Glutamate

young man has a history of headaches lasting 15-20 minutes, located over his orbit, associated with nasal congestion. His wife reports that he becomes irritated and angry during these episodes. What is the best treatment?

patient presents with a history of unilateral headache, severe, lasting less than 5 minutes, with stabbing pain and associated autonomic symptoms on the same side (tearing). What is the best approach for treatment?

question_text: What is the mechanism of action of Botox in the treatment of migraine headaches?

options.A: Serotonin agonist
patient presents with a headache that came out of the blue and has persisted for 3 months. What is the most likely diagnosis?

question_text: What is the second-line management for trigeminal neuralgia after carbamazepine?

options.A: Pregabalin
patient presents with a headache, normal brain CT, and lumbar puncture (LP) done by an intern that shows 48 WBCs, 780 RBCs, normal protein, and glucose. What is the most likely diagnosis?

question_text: In a patient with migraine without aura, which of the following is the most relevant clinical picture?

options.A: 30 to 60 minutes in duration

50-year-old male with a history of migraine has recently been diagnosed with myocardial infarction (MI) and coronary artery disease (CAD). What is contraindicated for use regarding preventive treatment of migraine?
MRI brain shows brainstem hyperintensities
options.B: PET scan shows changes in the diencephalon

options.A: Papilledema
options.B: Normal neurologic examination except for cranial nerve abnormalities
options.C: Neuroimaging: Normal brain parenchyma without evidence of hydrocephalus, mass, or structural lesion and no abnormal meningeal enhancement on MRI
options.D: Elevated lumbar puncture opening pressure (≥250 mm CSF in adults and ≥280 mm CSF in children)

options.A: young female presented with a severe headache; CT imaging shows pituitary apoplexy. What is the likely diagnosis?

postpartum patient who underwent a C-section presents with a headache that worsens upon standing and during Valsalva maneuver, and is not responding to medication. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_text: SUNCT and SUNA are characterized by sudden brief attacks of severe unilateral head pain in which regions?

options.A: Occipital and cervical
67-year-old patient with a history of severe bilateral temporal headache and a high ESR of 30 presents with sectoranopia (superior quadrant loss of vision).

question_text: The disruption within the Guillain-Mollaret triangle is associated with which type of palatal myoclonus?

options.A: Essential palatal myoclonus
patient with Parkinson's disease presented with peak dose dyskinesia. Which medication is most commonly used to manage this condition?
patient with progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) presents with impaired vertical gaze and axial rigidity. What is the diagnosis?

question_text: Essential palatal myoclonus is frequently associated with which of the following characteristics?

options.A: Muscle agonist is the tensor veli palatini
options.B: More persistent than symptomatic palatal myoclonus

options.A: young patient presents with dystonia and myoclonus. Which of the following is a characteristic feature of myoclonic-dystonia DYT11?
patient with frequent falls and vertical gaze palsy shows tectal atrophy on Brain MRI. What condition is most likely indicated?

question_text: Which type of palatal myoclonus is characterized by palatal movements due to contractions of the levator veli palatini and is often associated with other symptoms related to a causative lesion?

options.A: Essential palatal myoclonus
30-year-old male presents with a history of symmetrical action tremor that improves with alcohol. What is the most likely diagnosis?

question_text: An elderly male patient with a history suggestive of Parkinson's disease (tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia) presents for evaluation. What is the next step in management?

options.A: Levodopa/carbidopa trial

question_text: Axial brain CT shows bilateral caudate atrophy. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.A: Huntington disease
